In lofty strains while Poets sing</br>The triumphs of the Prussian King,</br>With equal zeal I join the quire,</br>And strive to animate my lyre;</br>But oh! — in vain — the strings rebel,</br>On Love the little traitors dwell:</br>Rosbach — immortal Rosbach — yields</br>To gentle Love, and Spitalfields.

Frantick with rage, and loss of fame,</br>I change my strings, and change my theme</br>To Fer'nand, foremost in the chace</br>Of Clermont, and his coward race:</br>My partial lyre in vain I try,</br>Each accent sinks into a sigh:</br>To Love the gallant, Fer'nand yields,</br>To gentle Love, and Spitalfields.

Again I glow — again essay</br>To celebrate the glorious day,</br>When mighty Marlbro' — more than man!</br>Pursu'd, O Pitt, thy Patriot Plan:</br>Alas!  my numbers faintly flow,</br>In vain I strive — in vain I glow;</br>To Love, to Love, the Patriot yields,</br>To gentle Love, and Spitalfields.

No longer now by glory fir'd,</br>By Fer'nand, Marl'bro, Pitt, inspir'd</br>Or Prussia's King: —  With homage due,</br>Heroes!  I humbly bend to you;</br>A softer genius rules my song,</br>Whose melting magic charms my tongue;</br>Adieu, ye Heroes! — Colin yields</br>To gentle Love, and Spitalfields.

And is it thus? — thou simple swain—</br>Are all thy noble efforts vain?</br>Then hie thee to thy Rosalind,</br>And sue the Syren to be kind;</br>Haply she'll cast a conscious eye,</br>In pity render sigh for sigh;</br>While Colin, happy Colin yields</br>To gentle Love, and Spitalfields.

Yet, if the tyrant turn away,</br>Nor listen to thy love-sick lay;</br>No longer nurse the Viper-flame,</br>But bravely quench it in the Teme:</br>Perhaps — she'll drop a brilliant tear;</br>A mighty boon!  while Colin yields</br>His Life to Love, and Spitalfields.</br>
